para.sentence: For p,z\in\mathbb{C} E_{p}\left(z\right)=z^{p-1}\Gamma\left(1-p,z\right).
Most properties of E_{p}\left(z\right) follow straightforwardly from those of \Gamma\left(a,z\right).
For an extensive treatment of E_{1}\left(z\right) see Chapter 6.
E_{p}\left(z\right)=z^{p-1}\int_{z}^{\infty}\frac{e^{-t}}{t^{p}}\mathrm{d}t.

When the path of integration excludes the origin and does not cross thenegative real axis (8.19.2) defines the principal value of E_{p}\left(z\right) , and unless indicated otherwise in the DLMF principal values are assumed.

E_{p}\left(z\right)=\int_{1}^{\infty}\frac{e^{-zt}}{t^{p}}\mathrm{d}t, if |\operatorname{ph}z|<\tfrac{1}{2}\pi, , E_{p}\left(z\right)=\frac{z^{p-1}e^{-z}}{\Gamma\left(p\right)}\int_{0}^{\infty }\frac{t^{p-1}e^{-zt}}{1+t}\mathrm{d}t, if |\operatorname{ph}z|<\tfrac{1}{2}\pi, \Re p>0.
Integral representations of Mellin–Barnes type for E_{p}\left(z\right) follow immediately from (8.6.11),(8.6.12), and (8.19.1).

subsection.title: Graphics

para.sentence: In Figures 8.19.2–8.19.5, height corresponds to the absolute value of the function and color to the phase.
See About Color Map.

subsection.sentence: Figure 8.19.2: E_{\frac{1}{2}}\left(x+iy\right) , -4\leq x\leq 4 , -4\leq y\leq 4 . Principal value. There is a branch cut along the negative real axis.
Figure 8.19.3: E_{1}\left(x+iy\right) , -4\leq x\leq 4 , -4\leq y\leq 4 . Principal value. There is a branch cut along the negative real axis.
Figure 8.19.4: E_{\frac{3}{2}}\left(x+iy\right) , -3\leq x\leq 3 , -3\leq y\leq 3 . Principal value. There is a branch cut along the negative real axis.
Figure 8.19.5: E_{2}\left(x+iy\right) , -3\leq x\leq 3 , -3\leq y\leq 3 . Principal value. There is a branch cut along the negative real axis.

para.sentence: E_{0}\left(z\right)=z^{-1}e^{-z}, if z\neq 0, E_{p}\left(0\right)=\frac{1}{p-1}, if \Re p>1, E_{n}\left(z\right)=\frac{(-z)^{n-1}}{(n-1)!}E_{1}\left(z\right)+\frac{e^{-z}} {(n-1)!}\sum_{k=0}^{n-2}(n-k-2)!(-z)^{k}, if n=2,3,\dots.

For n=1,2,3,\dots , E_{n}\left(z\right)=\frac{(-z)^{n-1}}{(n-1)!}(\psi\left(n\right)-\ln z)-\sum_{ \begin{subarray}{c}k=0\\ k\neq n-1\end{subarray}}^{\infty}\frac{(-z)^{k}}{k!(1-n+k)} , and E_{n}\left(z\right)=\frac{(-1)^{n}z^{n-1}}{(n-1)!}\ln z+\frac{e^{-z}}{(n-1)!} \sum_{k=1}^{n-1}(-z)^{k-1}\Gamma\left(n-k\right)+\frac{e^{-z}(-z)^{n-1}}{(n-1) !}\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\frac{z^{k}}{k!}\psi\left(k+1\right) , with |\operatorname{ph}z|\leq\pi in both equations.
For \psi\left(x\right) see §5.2(i).

When p\in\mathbb{C} E_{p}\left(z\right)=z^{p-1}\Gamma\left(1-p\right)-\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\frac{(-z )^{k}}{k!(1-p+k)} , E_{p}\left(z\right)=\Gamma\left(1-p\right)\left(z^{p-1}-e^{-z}\sum_{k=0}^{ \infty}\frac{z^{k}}{\Gamma\left(2-p+k\right)}\right), again with |\operatorname{ph}z|\leq\pi in both equations.
The right-hand sides are replaced by their limiting forms when p=1,2,3,\dots.
pE_{p+1}\left(z\right)+zE_{p}\left(z\right)=e^{-z}.
\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}z}E_{p}\left(z\right)=-E_{p-1}\left(z\right), , \frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}z}(e^{z}E_{p}\left(z\right))=e^{z}E_{p}\left(z \right)\left(1+\frac{p-1}{z}\right)-\frac{1}{z}.
For j=1,2,3,\dots , \frac{{\partial}^{j}E_{p}\left(z\right)}{{\partial p}^{j}}=(-1)^{j}\int_{1}^{ \infty}(\ln t)^{j}t^{-p}e^{-zt}\mathrm{d}t, if \Re z>0.
For properties and numerical tables see Milgram (1985), and also(when p=1 ) MacLeod (2002b).
E_{p}\left(z\right)=z^{p-1}e^{-z}U\left(p,p,z\right).
For U\left(a,b,z\right) see §13.2(i).
E_{p}\left(z\right)=e^{-z}\left(\cfrac{1}{z+\cfrac{p}{1+\cfrac{1}{z+\cfrac{p+1 }{1+\cfrac{2}{z+\cdots}}}}}\right), if |\operatorname{ph}z|<\pi.
See also Cuyt et al. (2008, pp. 277–285).
The general function E_{p}\left(z\right) is attained by extending the path in (8.19.2) across the negative real axis.
Unless p is a nonpositive integer, E_{p}\left(z\right) has a branch point at z=0.
For z\neq 0 eachbranch of E_{p}\left(z\right) is an entire function of p.

sentence.Math: E_{p}\left(ze^{2m\pi i}\right)=\frac{2\pi ie^{mp\pi i}}{\Gamma\left(p\right)} \frac{\sin\left(mp\pi\right)}{\sin\left(p\pi\right)}z^{p-1}+E_{p}\left(z\right), if m\in\mathbb{Z}, z\neq 0.

para.sentence: For n=1,2,3,\dots and x>0 , \frac{n-1}{n}E_{n}\left(x\right)<E_{n+1}\left(x\right)<E_{n}\left(x\right), \left(E_{n}\left(x\right)\right)^{2}<E_{n-1}\left(x\right)E_{n+1}\left(x\right), \frac{1}{x+n}<e^{x}E_{n}\left(x\right)\leq\frac{1}{x+n-1}, \frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}\frac{E_{n}\left(x\right)}{E_{n-1}\left(x\right) }>0.

\int_{z}^{\infty}E_{p-1}\left(t\right)\mathrm{d}t=E_{p}\left(z\right), if |\operatorname{ph}z|<\pi, \int_{0}^{\infty}e^{-at}E_{n}\left(t\right)\mathrm{d}t=\frac{(-1)^{n-1}}{a^{n} }\left(\ln\left(1+a\right)+\sum_{k=1}^{n-1}\frac{(-1)^{k}a^{k}}{k}\right), if n=1,2,\dots, \Re a>-1, \int_{0}^{\infty}e^{-at}t^{b-1}E_{p}\left(t\right)\mathrm{d}t=\frac{\Gamma \left(b\right)(1+a)^{-b}}{p+b-1}\*F\left(1,b;p+b;a/(1+a)\right), if \Re a>-1, \Re(p+b)>1.

\int_{0}^{\infty}E_{p}\left(t\right)E_{q}\left(t\right)\mathrm{d}t=\frac{L(p)+ L(q)}{p+q-1}, if p>0, q>0, p+q>1, where L(p)=\int_{0}^{\infty}e^{-t}E_{p}\left(t\right)\mathrm{d}t=\frac{1}{2p}F\left( 1,1;1+p;\tfrac{1}{2}\right), if p>0.
For the hypergeometric function F\left(a,b;c;z\right) see §15.2(i).
When p=1,2,3,\dots , L(p) can also be evaluated via (8.19.24).
For collections of integrals involving E_{p}\left(z\right) , especially for integer p , see Apelblat (1983, §§7.1–7.2) andLeCaine (1945).
For higher-order generalized exponential integrals seeMeijer and Baken (1987) and Milgram (1985).
